block.p: Museums and Sites

ALICE AUSTEN HOUSE, 2 Hylan Boulevard, Rosebank, Staten Island. This 17th-century farmhouse, converted to a Victorian cottage in the 19th century, was the home of the photographer Alice Austen. ''Sailing the Harbor: Alice's Tall Ships,'' photographs by Alice Austin 100 years ago; through Sept. 3. Hours: Thursdays through Sundays, noon to 5 p.m. Admission: $2; children 12 and under, free. Information: (718) 816-4506.
Museums and Sites

ALICE AUSTEN HOUSE, 2 Hylan Boulevard, Rosebank, Staten Island. This 17th-century farmhouse, converted to a Victorian cottage in the 19th century, was the home of the photographer Alice Austen. ''Sailing the Harbor: Alice's Tall Ships,'' photographs by Alice Austin 100 years ago; through Sept. 3. Hours: Thursdays through Sundays, noon to 5 p.m. Admission: $2; children 12 and under, free. Information: (718) 816-4506.

AMERICAN MUSEUM OF NATURAL HISTORY, Central Park West and 79th Street. ''Fighting Dinosaurs: New Discoveries From Mongolia,'' featuring one of the most famous fossil finds in the world; through Oct. 29. ''Mongolia Observed: Photographs Present and Past,'' featuring 40 color images by Robert Peck and black-and-white photographs by the explorer Ray Chapman Andrews from the 1920's and 30's. Imax films are ''To Be an Astronaut'' and ''Dolphins.'' In the Imax Theater tonight and tomorrow night at 9, ''Laser Aerosmith in 3-D''; at 10, ''Laser Led Zeppelin.'' Laser show tickets: $12. Museum hours: Sundays through Thursdays, 10 a.m. to 5:45 p.m.; Fridays and Saturdays, 10 a.m. to 8:45 p.m. Admission (suggested donation): $10 for adults; $7.50 for students and the elderly; $6 for children. Combination tickets are available. Information: (212) 769-5100; advance tickets: (212) 769-5200.

AMERICAN MUSEUM OF NATURAL HISTORY'S ROSE CENTER FOR EARTH AND SPACE, Central Park West at 81st Street. This 333,500-square-foot, seven-floor, 120-foot-high exhibition and research center includes the new Hayden Planetarium, the Cullman Hall of the Universe and the Gottesman Hall of Planet Earth. The Hayden Planetarium contains the Space Theater, presenting ''Passport to the Universe,'' and the Big Bang Theater, featuring narrated visual and audio effects simulating the beginning of the universe. ''Starry Nights: Fridays Under the Sphere,'' music tonight from 5:45 to 8, with Ron Affif. Free with admission; food and cash bar. ''Full Moon: Apollo Mission Photographs of the Lunar Landscape,'' from NASA's Apollo missions to the moon; through Sept. 23. Hours: Sundays through Thursdays, 10 a.m. to 5:45 p.m.; Fridays and Saturdays to 8:45 p.m. Space shows run throughout the day. Admission (suggested donation) to the American Museum of Natural History, which includes the Rose Center: $10; for students and the elderly, $7.50; children 12 and under, $6; under 2, free. Admission to the museum, the Rose Center and the Hayden Planetarium space show: $19; students and the elderly, $14; children 12 and under, $11.50; under 2, free. Information: (212) 769-5100. Reservations: (212) 769-5200.

MUSEUM OF THE CITY OF NEW YORK, Fifth Avenue at 103rd Street. ''New York Now 2000: Contemporary Work in Photography,'' through Oct. 15. ''Renewing a Block and the Spirit of Its People: Photographs of Carmel Hill, Harlem by Bill Foley,'' through Nov. 12. ''Under the El: City Life in 20th-Century Prints and Drawings,'' through Dec. 3. ''Elegant Plate: 300 Years of Precious Metals in New York,'' through Sept. 24. ''Noel Coward Centennial,'' through Nov. 5. ''The New York Century: World Capital, Hometown,'' through Feb. 4. ''New York: Songs of the City,'' through Sept. 10. Tomorrow at 1 p.m., ''Songs of Central Park,'' a free outdoor sing-along with singer Roslyn Burroughs, at the Dana Discovery Center, 110th Street near Fifth Avenue. Hours: Tuesdays 10 a.m. to 2 p.m., for registered groups only; Wednesdays through Saturdays, 10 a.m. to 5 p.m.; Sundays, noon to 5 p.m. Suggested admission: $7; the elderly, students and children, $4; families, $12. Information: (212) 534-1672.

MUSEUM OF JEWISH HERITAGE: A LIVING MEMORIAL TO THE HOLOCAUST, 18 First Place, at West Street and Battery Place, Battery Park City. Artifacts, documents, photographs, videos and film clips are included in exhibitions on the Holocaust and on Jewish life before and after World War II. ''Children of a Vanished World: Photographs by Roman Vishniac,'' through Oct. 20. Sunday from 2 to 3:30 p.m, a walking tour of important Jewish sites on Manhattan's Lower South Side, beginning at the museum. Hours: Sundays through Wednesdays, 9 a.m. to 5 p.m.; Thursdays until 8 p.m.; Fridays and the eves of Jewish holidays, 9 a.m. to 5 p.m.; closed Saturdays. Admission: $7; students and the elderly, $5; children 5 and under, free. Tickets can be bought in advance through Ticketmaster, (212) 307-4007, or by calling the museum on the day of the visit, (212) 945-0039. Information: (212) 509-6130.

NEW YORK CITY FIRE MUSEUM, 278 Spring Street, SoHo. In a renovated 1904 firehouse, a collection of fire-related art and artifacts from the 18th century to the present, including a fire engine, hose wagons, hats and toys. The exhibition ''Fire Marks: Emblems of Insurance'' features 18th- and 19th-century British and American emblems used by firefighters to distinguish policyholders from the uninsured. Hours: Tuesdays through Sundays, 10 a.m. to 4 p.m. Suggested admission: $4; $2, students and the elderly; $1, children under 12. Information: (212) 691-1303.
Gardens

BROOKLYN BOTANIC GARDEN, 900 Washington Avenue, Prospect Heights. Through Sept. 16, butterfly and hummingbird trails open for tours, with related crafts and other activities on weekends. The Japanese Hill and Pond Garden is open, with guided tours available. ''100 Flowers,'' botanical series by Harold Feinstein. Through August 20. Gallery hours: Tuesdays through Sundays, 10 a.m. to 5:30 p.m. Admission: $3; $1.50 for students and the elderly; free for children 15 and under; free on Tuesdays, except holidays; free from 10 a.m. to noon on Saturdays. Hours: Tuesdays through Fridays, 8 a.m. to 6 p.m.; Saturdays, Sundays and holidays, 10 a.m. to 6 p.m. The conservatory closes 30 minutes before the grounds. Information: (718) 623-7200.

NEW YORK BOTANICAL GARDEN, 200th Street and Kazimiroff Boulevard, Fordham, the Bronx. The grounds include more than 47 specialty gardens and plant collections. The Exotic Courtyard Garden is open through Sept. 24. Hours: Tuesdays through Sundays and Monday holidays, 10 a.m. to 6 p.m. Botanical garden admission: $3; students and the elderly, $2; children 2 to 12, $1; under 2, free. Grounds admission free for all on Wednesdays and from 10 a.m. to noon on Saturdays. There are combination packages. Parking: $5. The best way to see the garden is with a ''garden passport'' combination ticket, which grants admission to the entire grounds, with a tram tour: adults, $10; students and the elderly, $7.50; children 2 to 12, $4; under 2, free. Information: (718) 817-8700.

WAVE HILL, West 249th Street and Independence Avenue, Riverdale, the Bronx. Gardens, greenhouses and woodlands are part of the 28-acre garden and cultural institution. Sunday at 5 p.m, ''Choreographers From the Field,'' four emerging choreographers developing their work through the Field, a mentor program for young choreographers. Free with Wave Hill admission. Tuesdays through Sundays, 9 a.m. to 5:30 p.m. Admission: $4; students and the elderly, $2; Saturdays, free until noon. Information: (718) 549-3200.
Cruises

ADIRONDACK, leaving from Chelsea Piers Sports and Entertainment Complex, 23rd Street on the Hudson River. An 80-foot schooner that goes on two-hour sails daily at 10:30 a.m., 1, 3:30, 6 and 9 p.m. Tickets: weekdays, $30 for all sails except the 6 and 9 p.m. sail, which is $40, and includes drinks; weekends, $35 for all sails except the 6 and 9 p.m. sail. which is $45, including drinks. Information: (800) 701-7245.

CIRCLE LINE CRUISES, leaving from Pier 83, 42nd Street at the Hudson River, Clinton. A two-hour 24-mile cruise around southern Manhattan passing landmarks like Ellis Island and the United Nations, daily at 11 a.m., 2 and 4:30 p.m. Tickets: $20; children 12 and under, $10; the elderly, $16. A three-hour 35-mile cruise around all of Manhattan, daily at 9:30, 10:15 and 11:45 a.m., 12:30, 1:15, 2:45 and 3:30 p.m. Tickets: $24; children 12 and under, $12; the elderly, $19. ''Harbor Lights,'' daily at 7 p.m. Tickets: $20; children 12 and under, $10; the elderly, $16. ''The Beast,'' 30-minute speedboat ride in the harbor, daily, every hour on the hour, 11 a.m. to dusk, except Wednesdays, when it is 2 p.m. to dusk. Tickets: $15; children 5 to 12, $10. Information: (212) 563-3200.

WORLD YACHT, leaving from Pier 81, 41st Street at the Hudson River, Clinton. Daily dinner cruises along the West Side of Manhattan and around New York Harbor, from 7 to 10 p.m., boarding at 6 p.m. Prices: Fridays, $75; Saturdays, $79; Sundays, $67 (does not include beverages, taxes or gratuities). Brunch cruises sail on Sundays from 12:30 to 2:30 p.m., with boarding at 11:30 a.m. Price: $39.95. Information: (212) 630-8100.

N.Y. WATERWAY, leaving from Pier 78, West 38th Street and 12th Avenue, Manhattan. Daily two-hour full Manhattan cruise, at 10:30 a.m. and 1:30 p.m., through Nov. 12. Tickets: $24; $19 for the elderly; $12 for children ages 3 to 12; 2 and younger, free. Daily, a 90-minute cruise of New York Harbor; at 10 a.m., 11 a.m., noon, 1 p.m., 2, 3 and 4 p.m. Tickets: $19; the elderly, $16; ages 3 to 12, $9; 2 and younger, free. Fridays at 10:15 p.m., disco cruise. Price: $19; $9 for children. A 70-minute twilight tour leaves daily, except Tuesday, at 8:45 p.m.; additional tours on Saturdays at 7:15 and 10:15 p.m. and on Sundays at 7:15. Tickets: $19; the elderly, $16; children, $9. Information: (800) 533-3779.

PIONEER, the historic schooner, sails from the South Street Seaport Museum's Pier 16, South and Fulton Streets, for a two-hour cruise. Sunset cruises Tuesdays through Sundays at 7 p.m.; also 9:30 p.m. sails Tuesdays through Saturdays; additional sails Saturdays and Sundays at 1 and 4 p.m. Tickets: sunset cruises $25; other sails $20, $15 for students and the elderly and $12 for children 12 and under.
EVENTS

''SUNSET JAM ON THE HUDSON,'' Wagner Park, Battery Park City, Lower Manhattan. Featuring a rotating trio of percussionists: Mary Knyshok, Peter Hawes and Pamela Patrick. Tonight at 6:30. Free. Sponsored by Battery Park City Parks Conservancy. Information: (212) 267-9700.

''ROMEO AND JULIET,'' Harlem School of the Arts, Courtyard Theater, 645 St. Nicholas Avenue, near 141st Street. A hip-hop version of Shakespeare's work performed outdoors by the Classical Theater of Harlem. Thursdays through Sundays at 7:30 p.m. through Aug. 6; also Aug. 2 at 7:30 p.m. Tickets, $12; $10 for students and the elderly. Information: (212) 539-8828.

UPPER WEST SIDE ARTISTS. A visit to the studios of several artists, including Patricia Wynne, an illustrator; Maceo Mitchell, a painter, and Donald Mulligan and Jane Volpe, watercolorists. Sunday at 1 p.m. Fee, $20. Sponsored by the 92nd Street Y. Meeting place and other information: (212) 996-1100.

''CRUISING THE OTHER ISLANDS OF NEW YORK CITY,'' a look at some of the islands that dot the New York waterway, including Ellis and Rikers Island. Meets tomorrow at 9:30 a.m. at the foot of Old Fulton Street in Brooklyn and the East River, opposite the River Cafe. Sponsored by Brooklyn Center for the Urban Environment and the Roebling Chapter of the Society for Industrial Archaeology. Fee, $35; $30 for members, students and the elderly. Reservations: (718) 788-8500, extension 219.
RECREATION

DASH AND SPLASH, Central Park. A five-mile run, followed by a swim in Lasker Pool. Begins tomorrow at 8 a.m. on the 102nd Street transverse, west of the East Park Drive. Sponsored by the New York Road Runners Club. Advance registration fee, $17; $12 for members; $10 for junior and senior club members. Race-day registration: $22; $15 for members; $12 for junior and senior club members. Information: (212) 860-4455.
ON THE STREET

N.Y.C. UNFOLDS STREET FAIR, West Third Street, from Broadway to La Guardia Place, West Village. Annual fund-raiser for AIDS organizations. Tomorrow, 11 a.m. to 6 p.m. Portions of the AIDS memorial quilt will be on view. Sponsored by the New York City Chapter of the Names Project.
STONEWALL WAVERLY PLACE FESTIVAL, Broadway to Fifth Avenue. Tomorrow, 11 a.m. to 7 p.m. Sponsored by the Stonewall Democratic Club.
ASTORIA KIWANIS FESTIVAL, 31st Street, from Ditmars Boulevard to 23rd Avenue, Queens. Tomorrow, 11 a.m. to 7 p.m. Sponsored by the Queens West Kiwanis Foundation/Long Island City Kiwanis.
THIRD AVENUE SUMMERFEST, from 42nd to 57th Street. Sunday, 11 a.m. to 6 p.m. Sponsored by the East Side Re-zoning Alliance.
NEW YORK CITY MOVIE DAY FESTIVAL, Seventh Avenue, from 47th to 57th Street, Manhattan. Sunday, 11 a.m. to 6 p.m. Sponsored by the Motion Picture Club.
WALKING TOURS

YANKEE STADIUM, the Bronx. An insider's tour of the baseball arena, including Monument Park and the dugout. Meets today and tomorrow at noon at the press gate. Fee, $8; $4 for children 14 and younger and the elderly. The tour is repeated on many Fridays and Saturdays when the team is away. Information: (718) 579-4531.

''SOUTH STREET SEAPORT/DUTCH ORIGINS OF NEW YORK'' covers the area from South Ferry to the South Street Seaport. Tomorrow and Sunday at 11:45 a.m. Fee, $11. Sponsored by Gotham Walk. Meeting place and reservations: (212) 629-1886.

''BROOKLYN BRIDGE TO BROOKLYN HEIGHTS AT TWILIGHT,'' a walk across the bridge and through one of the city's first suburbs. Meets tomorrow at 5 p.m. on the southeast corner of Broadway and Chambers Streets at City Hall Park in Manhattan. Sponsored by Big Onion Walking Tours. Fee: $12; $10 for students and the elderly. Information: (212) 439-1090.

''SUTTON PLACE AND TREADWELL FARM DISTRICT,'' Manhattan. A tour of a well-to-do area with humble beginnings. Tomorrow at 4:45 p.m. and Sunday at 3:45 p.m. Sponsored by NYC Discovery Tours. Fee, $12. Reservations and meeting place: (212) 465-3331.

''BEHIND THE FENCES WALKING TOURS,'' Prospect Park, Brooklyn. A free tour of the park's newly restored ravine. Every Saturday at 3 p.m. and every Sunday at 1 and 3 p.m through November. Sponsored by the Prospect Park Alliance and the Urban Park Rangers. Information: (718) 965-6988.

''HARLEM: KEYSTONE OF AFRICAN AMERICA.'' The history, homes, churches and cultural and economic growth of the area. Meets tomorrow at 1 p.m. at City College, Amsterdam Avenue and 138th Street. Fee, $10. Sponsored by Joyce Gold History Tours of New York. Information: (212) 242-5762.

''FROM PAGES TO PAVEMENT,'' Manhattan. Includes locations mentioned in seven novels set in the gaslight era. Meets tomorrow at 2 p.m. at the arch in Washington Square. Fee: $10. Sponsored by Street Smarts N.Y. Information: (212) 969-8262.

''STANFORD WHITE: SPLENDOR AND SCANDAL,'' Lower Manhattan. Looks at the life of the architect and the buildings he designed. Meets tomorrow at 6 p.m. at the Washington Arch. Fee, $10. Sponsored by Street Smarts N.Y. Information: (212) 969-8262.

''JAZZ NIGHTS IN HARLEM.'' A tour of the area, followed by dinner and a stop at a jazz club. Meets tonight and tomorrow at 7:30 p.m. on the northeast corner of Lenox Avenue and 125th Street. Fee: $45. Sponsored by Harlem Heritage Tours. Reservations: (212) 280-7888.

THE BOWERY. A stroll on the historic thoroughfare past sites associated with Theodore Roosevelt, Mae West, George Washington and Abraham Lincoln. Sunday at 10 a.m. Fee, $18. Sponsored by the 92nd Street Y. Meeting place and other information: (212) 996-1100.

''THE JEWISH LOWER EAST SIDE.'' Explores the historic settlements, once home to one of the largest Jewish communities in the world. Meets Sunday at 1 p.m. on the southeast corner of Essex and Delancey Streets. Fee: $12, $10 for students and the elderly. Sponsored by Big Onion Walking Tours. Information: (212) 439-1090.

LITERARY GARRETS OF GREENWICH VILLAGE. Visits the homes or places of significance in the lives of Theodore Dreiser, Edna St. Vincent Millay, Edgar Allan Poe, Marianne Moore and others. Meets Sunday at 2 p.m. in front of the Jefferson Market Library, Avenue of the Americas and 10th Street. Fee, $12. Sponsored by Dr. Phil: New York Talks and Walks. Information: (718) 377-4455.

''GHOSTS ON BROADWAY.'' Visits haunted theaters and a hotel. Meets Sunday at 2 p.m. in front of the Belasco Theater, 44th Street near Avenue of the Americas. Fee: $10. Sponsored by Street Smarts N.Y. Information: (212) 969-8262.

''COSMOPOLITAN YORKVILLE,'' Manhattan, takes in Gracie Mansion, the City and Suburban Homes complex and the Henderson Place Historic District. Meets Sunday at 3:15 p.m. at the southwest corner of Lexington Avenue and 86th Street. Fee, $5. Sponsored by Adventure on a Shoestring. Information: (212) 265-2663.

''BUTTERFLIES AND DRAGONFLIES IN PROSPECT PARK,'' Brooklyn. Features a trip to ''Butterfly Meadow'' and the ponds where dragonflies congregate. Meets Sunday at 1 p.m. at the tennis house, near the Ninth Street entrance to the park. Sponsored by the Brooklyn Center for the Urban Environment. Fee, $8; $6 for members of the Center; $5 for students and the elderly. Information: (718) 788-8500, extension 401.

''MIDTOWN RECONFIGURED: THE GRAND CENTRAL AREA AND TUDOR CITY.'' Covers the skyscraper boom of the 1920's and 30's and the transformation of waterfront slums into Tudor City. Meets Sunday at 1 p.m. at the Philip Morris Building, at the southwest corner of Park Avenue and 42nd Street. Sponsored by the Municipal Art Society. Fee, $15; $12 for Society members. Information: (212) 935-3960.

HARLEM GOSPEL TOUR. A tour that includes stops at a church and several cultural institutions. Meets on Sunday at 10 a.m. on the southwest corner of Lenox Avenue and 116th Street. Fee: $20. Sponsored by Harlem Heritage Tours. Information: (212) 280-7888.
SPARE TIMES
